intro: Paepalanthus meseticola, commonly known as the Peruvian buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its small, showy flowers and capsule fruits. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils at high altitudes, thriving in the cool and humid climates of the Andes. Its leaves are usually alternate and have a distinctive hairy texture, while its flowers are yellow with four petals. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
